title: Bold Script from Pulp Book Cover
content:
Hello type geniuses!  
Any idea what this display font is? Perhaps there is a font similar?

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Flash For Freedom.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831130124/http:/typophile.com/files/Flash%20For%20Freedom.jpg) | 38.4 KB |
author: helvetica bold

comments.content:
Signet, New York, 1973 lettering probably from Photolettering but I don't know the name off hand. [BTW the sexist cover illustration is by Frank Frazetta.]  
F and underscore are probably custom artwork.  
Sansita One by Pablo Cosgaya at Omnibus-Type could be edited to produce the lettering:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831130124im_/http:/typophile.com/files/SansitaOneInUse_5116.jpg)
  
 [http://www.fontsquirrel.com/fonts/sansita-one](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831130124/http:/www.fontsquirrel.com/fonts/sansita-one "http://www.fontsquirrel.com/fonts/sansita-one")  
 [http://www.omnibus-type.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831130124/http:/www.omnibus-type.com/ "http://www.omnibus-type.com/")  
It has an Open Font License which permits this.  
Don
It has much in common with a manually slanted [Salut](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831130124/http:/www.fonts.com/font/monotype/salut).

Interesting. Here is Salut, slanted 11 degrees, to match Sansita.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831130124im_/http:/typophile.com/files/SalutSlanted11deg_4542.jpg)
  
Terminals on r and s are close to the mystery lettering, and it's a connected font.  
Combine Sansita and Salut and we are starting to generate a match.  
Don
You guys are awesome. I could picture Salut in my mind, I knew I had seen it but I didn't know the name. I'll try it a try but please let me know if you think of something else.

Nick Curtis did a version of Salut using the name Unicorn.  
Don

Interestingly, Nick's naming of Unicorn was surely derived from Alan Meeks' reworking of Salut - which he called Einhorn. I wonder why, when Unicorn is clearly based on Salut rather than Einhorn.

[http://old.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/einhorn/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831130124/http:/old.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/einhorn/ "http://old.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/einhorn/")

Thanks Mike for the followup. I love trying to set straight the provenance of interesting fonts.  
Don
As do I, Don. You clearly have lots more resources than I, though - so I read most everything you write on this forum with interest.

I supplement web resources with a few printed books. Wish I had more.  
Don

The uppercase letters in Einhorn are less cartoony than Salut.  
I prefer Einhorn a lot more.
